Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; well detailed back with some modelling for head and clypeus, and simple incised divisions in single line for prothorax and elytra, and triangular winglets on either side; underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, giving the name of Amun-Ra with three redundant vertical strokes (usual mark of the plurial in Ancient Egyptian); inscription stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; pale yellow glaze relatively well preserved, slightly more greenish on the level of the scarab's legs; pale yellow paste.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Variants of the name of Amun-Ra are a common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 89-93; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 25; on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab was discovered in the “Scarab Factory” itself with another similar scarab (signaled on the drawing Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 91), likely BM 1886,0401.1661. These scarabs belong to the type XXVIII B in Gorton 1996, which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 101-107). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 91)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.088) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musée du Louvre, Paris
